On Wednesday, February 22, will be observed the twenty-fifth anniversary of the initiation of the work of the University. By the
will of Johns, Hopkins, the most of his large
estate was bequeathed to a board of trustees,
whom he had previously selected, to manage
the University and Hospital that bear his name.
Of these trustees Galloway Cheston was president. The remaining members of the board
were George W. Dobbin, George William
Brown, Francis King, Thomas M. Smith,
James Carey Thomas, Charles J. M. Gwinn,
Lewis N. Hopkins, Reverdy Johnson, Jr., and
Francis White. Their first meeting after Mr.
Hopkins' death was held February 6, 1874, so
that just twenty-five years have passed since
they undertook their responsibility.
Only three of the members of the board are
now living, namely : Francis White, treasurer ; Lewis N. Hopkins, secretary, and Reverdy Johnson, who was for several years chairman of the executive committee.
In commemoration of this beginning of
the work, the trustees have requested President
Gilman to deliver a discourse on The History
and Prospects of the Johns Hopkins University. The exercises will be held in McCoy Hall
and as usual everyone belonging to the University is expected to be present. A number
of degrees will be conferred. It is expected
that on that day recently painted portraits of
Professor Sylvester and of Professor Remsen
will be presented to the University.
The Alumni Association of the University
will hold its annual dinner on the evening of
Commemoration Day at the Rennert. Rev.
Maltbie D. Babcock, D. D., pastor of Brown
Memorial Church, will speak on The Proper
Relations of College Men to the Poor and the
Afflicted in a Large City. Professor Osler,
and Judge McSherry of the Court of Appeals
will also make after-dinner speeches. The arrangements for the dinner are in the hands of
the Executive Committee.

II. Long-Distance Running.

By long-distance running is understood a
race of one-half mile or over, the usual distances being 88o yards, one, and three miles.
I. GENERAL CONDITIONS.

(a) Physical Examination.—No one should
begin to train for any athletic contest without an assurance that his heart and lungs
are in good condition.
(b) Preliminary Work.—Should be begun
in the gymnasium in the winter and should
consist of a general development, especial attention being paid to the chest and arms. A
runner not infrequently tires in his arms before
his legs are exhausted. All kinds of heavy
work render the muscles sluggish and should
be avoided.
(c) Diet.—It is just as necessary to cultivate a good, strong stomach as a good pair of
legs. This can only be done by at all times
abstaining from articles of food and drink
which cause indigestion. The question of diet
is largely a personal matter. In general, however, the following articles are tabooed in season and out of season : Alcoholic liquors, tobacco, mince pie, boiled cabbage, etc. In general, meats and eggs tend to produce strength,
while carbohydrates (brea(l, fruits and vegetables) induce flesh. A person should be governed by no hard and fast rules in the matter
of diet, hut should take such food and in such
quantities as his appetite demands.
(d) Baths and Massage are very helpful.
The bath should be begun warm, and gradually
tempered down to cold.

II. Long-Distance Running.

By long-distance running is understood a
race of one-half mile or over, the usual distances being 88o yards, one, and three miles.
I. GENERAL CONDITIONS.

(a) Physical Examination.—No one should
begin to train for any athletic contest without an assurance that his heart and lungs
are in good condition.
(b) Preliminary Work.—Should be begun
in the gymnasium in the winter and should
consist of a general development, especial attention being paid to the chest and arms. A
runner not infrequently tires in his arms before
his legs are exhausted. All kinds of heavy
work render the muscles sluggish and should
be avoided.
(c) Diet.—It is just as necessary to cultivate a good, strong stomach as a good pair of
legs. This can only be done by at all times
abstaining from articles of food and drink
which cause indigestion. The question of diet
is largely a personal matter. In general, however, the following articles are tabooed in season and out of season : Alcoholic liquors, tobacco, mince pie, boiled cabbage, etc. In general, meats and eggs tend to produce strength,
while carbohydrates (brea(l, fruits and vegetables) induce flesh. A person should be governed by no hard and fast rules in the matter
of diet, hut should take such food and in such
quantities as his appetite demands.
(d) Baths and Massage are very helpful.
The bath should be begun warm, and gradually
tempered down to cold.

a good liniment, but the rubbing is more important than the material used.

The meal prior to a race should be a light

The second annual meeting of the Hopkins

January 19, the anniversary of General Lee's
birth. Several photographs of General Lee,
together with a number of specimens of manuscript written while he was in command at
West Point, and later when he was President

University, and will be placed in the Donovan
Room. Mr. Hulliken was elected president of

Canter secretary, and an executive committee
was appointed.
Shortly after the death of Dr. Louis E. Livingood in the La Bourgogne disaster of July
last, it was proposed to establish a permanent
memorial to him in connection with the Pathological Department of the Johns Hopkins
Hospital, in which he was an associate, and in
which he took particular interest. This movement originated among the men of Princeton,
where Dr. Livingood was graduated in 189o,
hut it soon spread to this University. Under
the direction of Dr. J. M. T. Finney, a considerable fund has been collected. The memorial
will probably consist of a collection of pathological books suitably inscribed to commemorate the honesty of purpose and remarkable
degree of success which were typified in the
life of Dr. Livingood.

New York, recently lectured here on the extension of university methods and ideas to the

social problems that stare us in the face by inculcating the proper ideas in the minds of the
country children, and by arousing in them an
